Electrocatalysis is key to improving energy efficiency, reducing carbon emissions, and providing a sustainable way of meeting global energy needs. Therefore, elucidating electrochemical reaction mechanisms at the electrolyte/electrode interfaces is essential for developing advanced renewable energy technologies. However, the direct probing of real-time interfacial changes, i.e., the surface intermediates, chemical environment, and electronic structure, under operating conditions is challenging and necessitates the use of in situ methods. Herein, we present a new lab-based instrument commissioned to perform in situ chemical analysis at liquid/solid interfaces using ambient pressure X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (APXPS). This setup takes advantage of a chromium source of tender X-rays and is designed to study liquid/solid interfaces by the “dip and pull” method. Each of the main components was carefully described, and the results of performance tests are presented. Using a three-electrode setup, the system can probe the intermediate species and potential shifts across the liquid electrolyte/solid electrode interface. In addition, we demonstrate how this system allows the study of interfacial changes at gas/solid interfaces using a case study: a sodium–oxygen model battery. However, the use of APXPS in electrochemical studies is still in the early stages, so we summarize the current challenges and some developmental frontiers. Despite the challenges, we expect that joint efforts to improve instruments and the electrochemical setup will enable us to obtain a better understanding of the composition–reactivity relationship at electrochemical interfaces under realistic reaction conditions. Graphical Abstract A new lab-based ambient pressure X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (APXPS) technique was used to probe liquid/solid and gas/solid interfaces in electrochemical systems. Keywords Tender X-rays Ambient pressure X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy Electrocatalysis Liquid/solid interface Gas/solid interface 1 Introduction Growing interest in the development of highly efficient energy conversion and storage systems has motivated the study of electrochemical interfaces in fuel cells, batteries, and electrolyzers [ 1–3 ]. Although most investigations to date have focused on material engineering to lower the polarization resistance at the electrodes or interfaces, it is crucial to understand the operando chemistry of interfacial electrochemical reactions. However, electrochemical interfaces are often complex, involving different phases with multiple reaction intermediates and products. Moreover, the chemical, geometrical, and electronic properties of the interface affect the elementary processes and, consequently, the system performance undergoes dynamic changes. Thus, resolving the respective roles is vital but not trivial, especially at the atomic scale. Classical electrochemical measurements are useful for providing kinetic and thermodynamic information regarding a system. However, there has been a growing demand over the last decade for the introduction of new methodologies to complement these measurements and allow us to understand the true chemical nature and electronic structures of active working interfaces. Obtaining such local information is necessary to obtain a better mechanistic understanding of interfacial electrochemistry and a deeper insight into the rational design of highly active electrocatalysts. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) is a well-developed surface science technique but has not been used extensively in electrochemical studies. Using core-and valence-level photoelectrons, XPS has been used to probe the chemical compositions, oxidation states, and electronic structures of surfaces with sub-monolayer sensitivity. In addition, the changes in the kinetic energy of the ejected photoelectrons can be used to measure local built-in electric potentials. However, although XPS is a frequently used tool for the ex situ characterization of electrocatalytic materials, there is concern that metastable species might only be present under reaction conditions, thus necessitating in situ measurements [ 4,5 ]. Therefore, XPS measurements must be adapted to operate under higher pressures than the ultra-high vacuum (UHV) typically required, thus allowing the direct capture of changes in the working electrocatalyst; this has been key to instrument development, as shown by research dating back to the 1970s [ 6 ]. These continuous efforts over the last fifty years have successfully extended the XPS pressure regime to several tens of millitorr [ 7,8 ], that is, ambient-pressure XPS (APXPS), and these developments have even enabled the use of synchrotron radiation [ 9,10 ]. The further combination of APXPS with electrochemical methods has resulted in many exciting applications and has answered questions that are impossible in ex situ studies. In particular, electrochemical APXPS has the inherent capability to probe local potentials in a non-contact manner [ 11–14 ], providing a convenient tool to isolate the electric contributions from those originating from chemical reactions. Although there has been rapid growth in the use of APXPS over the past decade, its application in electrochemical investigations is still emerging, and there remain many opportunities and challenges [ 15 ]. Currently, there is increasing interest in expanding its use in liquid studies. However, a key technical obstacle is that the detection of meaningful photoelectron signals at a liquid/solid interface is challenging because of the significant inelastic scattering of electrons in condensed matter. However, a few approaches can be used to probe the liquid/solid interface from the solid or liquid side. For example, by employing an electron-transparent graphene membrane, one can seal the liquid from the vacuum XPS chamber and detect photoelectrons from the solid side (i.e., the graphene membrane side) [ 16–18 ]. Further, the supported graphene can be used as a working electrode. A second approach is to take advantage of the “dip and pull” method and carry out photoelectron detection from the liquid side of the interface [ 19 ]. Other schemes include utilizing thin windows and ion-exchange membrane cells [ 5,20–22 ]. Although each method has its own advantages and experimental restrictions, the “dip and pull” approach is favored because it imposes fewer restrictions on sample preparation and, thus, allows a broader range of solid electrode materials having the desired thicknesses. This configuration also allows the study of the electric potential drop across the electrode/electrolyte interface [ 23 ]. In this work, we discuss how interfacial phenomena can be examined using APXPS as a surface science tool (Fig. 1 ). Our goal here is to introduce APXPS to an electrochemistry-focused audience by showing how a lab-based APXPS instrument works and how this technique can be applied to obtain in situ and operando information. Beginning with a brief discussion of the general principles and experimental considerations that have motivated and guided instrument design, we present an overview of a newly built lab-based APXPS system for operando spectroscopic measurements of liquid/solid interfaces. We then present the performance of the instrument and select experimental examples of how APXPS helps us understand the electrochemical properties of the working interfaces. Finally, a recurring theme throughout this article is the synergy between the development of new tools and the discovery of new things: our desire to explore new electrochemical phenomena is a key driving force of instrumentation improvement and methodology development, and, vice versa, the advancement of new techniques can promote our understanding of electrocatalysis and help “discover new things that have to be explained” [ 10,24 ]. 2 Design goals 2.1 General considerations Carrying out electron spectroscopy experiments in the presence of liquids has system specifications that are quite different from those of typical vacuum or gas studies with soft X-ray sources. In general, the optimal photon energies for probing liquid/solid interfaces are higher than those under vacuum conditions. In particular, electron attenuation is the limiting factor for non-vacuum electron spectroscopy experiments, so previous efforts have employed strategies to limit the path length for electrons traveling in the ambient gas phase and employed small apertures with differentially pumped lens systems. These approaches have significantly bridged the so-call “pressure gap” and enabled photoelectron measurements in gaseous environment for studies of heterogeneous catalysis and environmental catalysis [ 25,26 ]. However, in challenging cases, for example, when a higher pressure condition is preferred, the kinetic energies of the emitted photoelectrons must be higher to increase electron transmission. This is achievable by using higher photon energies because the kinetic energy of the photoelectrons for a given subshell increases linearly with photon energy. High-energy photoelectrons can also benefit from their reduced scattering with gas molecules, thus yielding a detectable signal at relatively higher gas pressures. However, increasing the photon energy above the absorption threshold leads to a general decrease in the photoionization cross section. Thus, when choosing the optimum photon energy for high-pressure measurements, we must consider both the intensity gain through lower attenuation at high kinetic energies and the signal loss due to the decreased excitation cross section. As an approximation, pressures above 5 Torr require photon energies at the upper end of the soft X-ray range, and this also applies to studies of liquids. In contrast, liquid films having thicknesses of 10–30 nm require photon energies in the tender X-ray range in order to maximize overall photoelectron transmission [ 19 ]. For further details, we refer readers to several good reviews and previous studies [ 7–10,15 ]. Here, with our focus on liquid/solid studies, we briefly note the relevant design requirements and desirable features for this APXPS system: (1) The development of a monochromatic X-ray source in the range of tender X-rays (2–7 keV photon energy) with high flux and small spot size. (2) The allowance of an operating pressure of up to 30 Torr for photoelectron measurements of (aqueous) liquids with reasonable energy resolution. (3) The easy switching between UHV and ambient pressure conditions without contaminating sample surfaces. (4) The flexible use of various sample environments and cell geometries. 2.2 Technical considerations for electrochemical studies The extension of APXPS to electrochemical studies places additional requirements on instrument design. First, to study electrochemical phenomena using spectroscopy, the electrochemical processes occurring at the measurement spot must be controlled, reproducible, and realistic. In particular, the electrode morphology and cell geometry can affect our spectral observations [ 27,28 ], so it is necessary to tailor the electrode structure or modify the cell design to guarantee the accurate probing of the interfacial phenomenon of interest, and this flexibility is a key instrument design requirement. In addition, there must be well-defined hydrodynamics at the electrodes to allow a direct link between spectroscopic information and the cell performance, as obtained using conventional electrochemical measurements [ 29 ]. Similarly, this also requires system flexibility to enable the upgrading of the cell geometry to that compatible with comparable online and offline kinetic analyses. Given that the application of APXPS to electrochemical measurements is still in its early stages, it is wise to begin experimental explorations in a lab-based system. As a complement to synchrotron-based APXPS, lab-based systems can provide more space for risky experiments and more time to map parameters over a large range. 3 APXPS system The APXPS instrument reported here is dedicated to in situ and operando photoelectron studies using both the “dip and pull” method and customized electrochemical cells. It consists of three main components: (1) a chromium X-ray source, (2) main analysis chamber, and (3) electron energy analyzer. As shown in the schematic (Figs. 2(a) and 2(b) ), the X-ray source and electron energy analyzer are connected through the analysis chamber, in which the incoming X-rays are perpendicular to the axis of the pre-lens of the electron energy analyzer. To maximize the signal count, the sample in the analysis chamber is positioned at near-grazing incidence for normal emissions. The entire system operates with six turbo molecular pumps (STP-301, Edwards): one for each X-ray source and the analysis chamber and four for the electron energy analyzer. The details of each component are described in the following sections. 3.1 X-ray source A Cr X-ray anode source with a monochromator was installed in the system to generate tender X-rays (Cr-Kα , 5.4 keV). The anode was designed by Kobayashi et al. and manufactured by Chemitronics Co., Ltd. [ 30,31 ]. Here, we provide a brief description of the X-ray source. Under typical working conditions, an electron gun operating at an accelerating voltage of 30 keV (Kimball Physics, EMG-4210) is used to generate a 2-mA electron beam. The microfocused beam bombards a water-cooled Cr target, thus producing X-rays. The emitted Cr-Kα X-rays are then monochromated and focused by an elliptically bent germanium crystal ((422) reflection) with a 730-mm Rowland circle. By design, the X-ray source can deliver 0.3-eV-wide X-rays having a photon energy of 5.4 keV, a photon flux of approximately 2.5 × 109 photons/s, and a beam size of 159 µm (horizontal) × 142 µm (vertical). As the X-ray beam enters the analysis chamber at a grazing incidence of approximately 5°, the footprint of the beam is elongated to around 1.8 mm in the horizontal direction. The X-ray source is vacuum-pumped using a dry-scroll vacuum pump (nXDS15i, Edwards) equipped with a turbomolecular pump (STP-301, Edwards) and is separated from the analysis chamber by a 200 µm-thick beryllium membrane window (99% purity, 30-mm diameter) glued to the X-ray source exit flange. This Be window can sustain a pressure difference of 760 Torr and allows 88% transmittance of 5.4-keV photons. Tests with Ar gas have confirmed that a pressure in the 1.0 × 10–9 Torr range can be maintained in the monochromator, while the pressure of the analysis chamber is increased up to 30 Torr. For safety purposes, two gauges are used as the interlocks for the X-ray source. As a safety measure, if the pressure of the Cr target or the monochromator exceeds 5 × 10–7 Torr, the electron gun is automatically stopped. 3.2 Analysis chamber The analysis chamber is made of µ-metal (a nickel-iron soft alloy) for magnetic shielding. The design of the chamber is versatile, providing flexibility to accommodate different experiments with non-standard sample geometries or user-specialized cell configurations. Further, it includes 18 ports for sample manipulation, pumping, gas dosing, and future extensions to the setup. The chamber is connected to the X-ray source through a six-inch conflate flange. As mentioned previously, the X-ray beam port is oriented at 90° with respect to the electron energy analyzer lens axis to enable grazing incidence and normal emission. To allow convenient sample loading and easy access to the chamber interior, a 10-inch load-lock-style port is included, and the door flange is equipped with an O-ring Viton seal for ambient pressure measurements that can be changed to fit a standard copper gasket for UHV studies. As described above, the analysis chamber was sealed from the X-ray source by a Be window. Similarly, the environment can be isolated from the electron energy analyzer to protect the respective pressures. This is realized by pressing a wobble stick with a Viton lid against the entrance cone of the analyzer. Therefore, the analysis chamber containing the experimental setup can be rapidly vented without breaking the vacuum of the X-ray source or electron energy analyzer. 3.2.1 Vacuum system and gas delivery The chamber was designed to allow photoelectron measurements under vacuum and ambient conditions of up to 30 Torr for surface science and (electro) catalytic studies, respectively. This controlled reaction atmosphere was achieved using a pumping and gas dosing system in the analysis chamber. The analysis chamber was pumped using a tandem turbomolecular and backing pump. Base pressures of 10–8 Torr are typically reached. If higher pressures are desired during the photoelectron measurement, the two pumps are stopped, and the chamber is pumped only through the cone aperture. The analysis chamber allows the simultaneous use of up to three standard and user-defined gases. The reaction gas was injected into the chamber via an adjustable leak valve (59.0 UHV, VAT). This provides flexibility to dose pure gas or gas mixtures at total pressures between 1.0 × 10–8 and 760 Torr into the analysis chamber. The gas composition can be controlled by adjusting the partial pressures of the reaction gases. The pressure of the analysis chamber is measured using an ion gauge (Agilent, UHV-24p) for high vacuum, and this is backed up by a capacitance diaphragm gauge (Agilent, CDG500T1000VCR8) for operando pressure measurements between 1 and 1000 Torr, as well as a capacitance diaphragm gauge (Agilent, CDG500T0001VCR8) to cover the range of 0.001 to 1 Torr. 3.2.2 Sample manipulation The system is equipped with two independent manipulators. The top manipulator is a home-built manipulator providing four-axis control (XYZ and rotation) and four separate BNC feedthroughs. The computer-controlled XYZ motor system with bellows (triple-axis compact, 4.5” flange, 4” travel, MDC) enables sample positioning with submicron precision. Further, the manipulator allows horizontal movement at a speed of 100 μm s–1 and vertical movement at 50 μm s–1. This precise control of sample movement is important for in situ photoelectron measurements because a failure to fine-tune the sample-to-aperture distance can lead to deviations in the sample surface conditions from the desired experimental settings and, consequently, inaccurate measurements [ 32 ]. The rotation is realized via a differentially pumped rotary platform (rotatable axis, 360, 4.5” flange, MDC). This custom-built manipulator is compatible with a variety of sample platens to meet different experimental requirements. For typical gas/solid investigations, modified STLC platens (Thermionics) can be used for experiments involving heating, cooling, or electrochemistry [ 33 ]. For liquid/solid studies, we employed a specially designed poly-ether-ether-ketone (PEEK) electrode housing to enable electrical connections from inside the chamber to an external potentiostat through the feedthroughs. The current design of the electrode housing can support three electrodes (working, reference, and counter electrodes) for electrochemical control and measurement, which should be sufficient for most electrochemical studies. If required, it can be further modified to accommodate up to four independent electric controls. The bottom manipulator, which has two-inches of motorized travel range, was designed to hold a container for liquid electrolytes. Therefore, this system can carry out the “dip and pull” experiments, where electrodes are dipped into a liquid electrolyte to create the liquid/solid interface for photoelectron measurements under electrochemical control. More details of the “dip and pull” method are given in the next section. For studies involving photochemistry or photoelectrochemistry, artificial sunlight can be introduced through a viewport directly facing the sample measurement position or through the front aperture from the electron energy analyzer. 3.3 Electron energy analyzer The electron energy analyzer is a HiPP-2 hemispherical analyzer supplied by Scienta Omicron [ 19,34,35 ]. It consists of a differentially pumped electrostatic pre-lens, receiving lens, and hemispherical analyzer with a 200-mm mean radius. As previously described, a wobble stick with a Viton lid pressed against the entrance aperture can isolate the pre-lens from the analysis chamber, thus maintaining the UHV of the analyzer when the analysis chamber is at high pressures. When using a 0.1-mm entrance aperture, the electron energy analyzer can maintain a pressure difference of nine orders of magnitude (between the analysis chamber and hemispherical analyzer) and detect photoelectrons having kinetic energies up to 10 keV [ 19 ]. The pre-lens was separated from the analysis chamber by an interchangeable titanium cone (45° half angle) with a small entrance aperture to limit the gas flow. The diameter of the entrance aperture can be varied from 0.1 to 0.8 mm but should be consistent with the desired operating pressure (i.e., a small aperture for high-pressure conditions) while ensuring reasonable photoelectron signal (i.e., a large aperture for maximizing signal count). In typical (aqueous) liquid/solid interface studies, a 0.3-mm diameter aperture is used to sustain a water vapor pressure of 30 Torr in the analysis chamber while maintaining a pressure in the detector section of the analyzer of less than 1.0 × 10–6 Torr. For cases where the vapor pressure of the liquid is low (e.g., ionic liquids) or where the gas/solid interface is of interest, a larger front aperture diameter is recommended to maximize the signal. Another aspect worth noting is that the aperture size should closely match the extended footprint of the X-ray beam on the sample surface to maximize the geometric acceptance of the photoelectrons. In addition, coatings can be applied to the front cone to prevent corrosion in experiments involving acidic or alkaline electrolytes. The HiPP-2 analyzer features a shaped mesh as one of the lens elements in the pre-lens to enable the detection of electrons with high kinetic energies at high pressures [ 19 ]. This shaped mesh design is beneficial for a larger angular acceptance, suppressed corona discharge, and the freedom to have a sharper front cone for improved access to the sample position. The lens tables were optimized for high transmission at kinetic energies between 53 and 10000 eV, and the analyzer energy resolution can reach 100 meV at room temperature, depending on the selection of the pass energy and entrance slit size. The pass energy can be selected between 5 and 500 eV, having a bandwidth of approximately 8% of the pass energy and a slit size between 0.1 and 4.0 mm. The influence of these two parameters on the instrument performance is further discussed in Section 4. 4 System performance In this section, we demonstrate the performance of the instrument, which was commissioned in June 2021, and discuss some of the key measurement parameters. Unless otherwise stated, a front cone with 0.3-mm diameter was used for the results reported in this work. The binding energy (BE) values were calibrated to the Au 4f 7/2 core level at 84.0 eV, and, after subtraction of the Shirley-type background, the spectra were normalized to the intensity of the low-BE background region. 4.1 System energy resolution and key parameters The system performance was tested in UHV on a gold (100-nm-thick Au)-coated silicon wafer that shared a common ground with the electron energy analyzer. The stability tests and high-resolution core-level results are shown in Figs. S1 and 3, respectively. By fitting the experimental data, we obtained the full width at half maximum (FWHM) of the Au 4f 7/2 peak. From the FWHM values, we estimated the system energy resolution (contributed by both the X-ray source and the electron energy analyzer) using the Voigt function (LA(2,2,0)) that incorporates the Lorentz and Gaussian broadening effects and has an accuracy of 0.02% [ 36 ]. (1) FWHM exp = 0.5346 α L + ( 0.2166 α L 2 + α G 2 ) Here, FWHMexp is the experimentally determined FWHM, αL is the Lorentzian broadening contribution arising from the core-hole lifetime, and α G is the combined Gaussian contribution arising from temperature broadening and the resolutions of the X-rays and electron energy analyzer. In this case, the natural linewidth of the 4f 7/2 transition for metallic Au is 330 meV [ 37 ] and using Gaussian temperature broadening of 90 meV [ 38 ], we extracted the energy resolution of this system, as summarized in Fig. S2. In particular, this demonstrates how the pass energy and slit size affect the energy resolution. To explain exactly what these two parameters are, we consider how the electron energy analyzer works. Once collected, the photoelectrons are retarded by the pre-lens and focused onto the entrance slit of the analyzer. The analyzer is set to a given energy, and only electrons that match this energy are refocused onto the analyzer exit slit and travel to the detector, thus yielding a signal. This set energy is called the so-called pass energy (PE). In most spectral acquisitions, the PE of the analyzer is held constant, and it is the pre-lens system that is responsible for retarding electrons to the energy range accepted by the analyzer. As mentioned in the previous section, the electron energy analyzer allows a bandwidth of approximately 8% of the pass energy. Thus, increasing the PE can contribute to a better signal-to-noise ratio but will, unavoidably, lead to decreased spectral resolution. As shown in Figs. 3(a)–(c) , changing the PE from 100 to 500 eV (while keeping other parameters unchanged) improved the overall intensity of the spectra, but the FWHM of the Au 4f 7/2 core-level peak also increased from 536 to 1042 meV, which corresponds to the energy broadening of the system from 312 to 847 meV (Fig. S2). The variation in entrance slit size also showed similar results. The spectra plotted in Figs. 3(b), (e), and (h) showed good signal-to-noise gain on increasing the slit size from 0.5 to 4.0 mm (at a PE of 200 eV), but they also demonstrated an increase in peak FWHM from 575 to 931 meV because of the energy broadening, which changed from 357 to 733 meV. Based on our performance tests, a PE of 200 eV and an entrance slit size of 1.5 mm are optimal for routine measurements, assuming a system energy resolution of approximately 500 meV. This is consistent with previously reported values by Kobayashi et al. [ 30 ] and Regoutz et al. [ 39 ]. In most cases, it is desirable to find an optimized setting of the PE and entrance slit size to balance the signal-to-noise ratio and energy resolution. However, if extreme conditions are used, which make obtaining a sufficient signal intensity or energy resolution challenging, tuning these two parameters provides freedom to facilitate data collection. We also evaluated the effect of the incident angle, θ (Fig. 2(b)). Because the penetration depth of X-rays in condensed matter is much larger than that of emitted photoelectrons, the X-rays usually reach the sample surface at small incident angles, accompanied by photoelectrons collected along the surface normal, especially in hard X-ray photoelectron studies [ 39,40 ]. This geometry, on one hand, enhances photoionization in near-surface regions where the ejected photoelectrons can escape, but, on the other hand, ensures the deepest probing depth through normal emissions. However, decreasing θ can also lead to an elongated X-ray beam footprint and, consequently, a loss in the signal intensity. Therefore, grazing-incidence measurements were performed to determine the optimal incidence angle. Fig. 4(a) shows the Au 3d 5/2 spectra obtained from the Au-coated Si wafer between incident angles of 1° and 20°. The observed peak position and FWHM did not change as the incidence angle was varied. Fig. 4(b) shows the integrated intensity of the Au 3d 5/2 peak as a function of θ, along with the width of the X-ray footprint (in the horizontal direction). As the incident angle decreased from 20° to 5°, the photoelectron intensity showed only a small increase of approximately 15%. However, once it passed 5°, the signal intensity showed a sharp decrease as θ decreased by >50% from 5° to 1°. In contrast, the X-ray footprint elongated continuously. At an incident angle of 5°, the width of the X-ray footprint on the sample surface reached 1.8 mm, i.e., six times the diameter of the front cone aperture (0.3 mm). A further decrease in the incident angle was, in reality, a negative contribution to the signal intensity, although the small enhancement in the near-surface photoelectrons was preserved. This observation is consistent with theoretical calculations using the field-of-view limited model [ 41 ]. Hence, we determined an optimal incident angle of 5° for our system. 4.2 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy at ambient pressures With the optimized analyzer setting of 200 eV PE, 1.5-mm entrance slit size, and 5° incident angle, we tested the instrument under an argon atmosphere at ambient pressures. Fig. 5 shows the Au 3d 5/2 spectra collected under UHV and different Ar pressures of up to 30 Torr. With increasing gas pressure, substantial attenuation in the intensity of the Au 3d 5/2 peak was observed. The logarithm of the integrated signal intensity, which is plotted in Fig. 5(b) as a function of the Ar pressure, showed a linear relationship. This indicates that the photoelectron signal attenuation is solely due to the inelastic scattering of electrons by gas molecules, and this is consistent with previous reports of APXPS measurements [ 42,43 ]. In addition, when applying a Voigt fitting to the spectra, we did not observe any spectral broadening as a function of pressure (Fig. S3). This confirmed that the gas atmosphere had a minor influence on the peak features, except for a general increase in the background. The performance test results shown in Fig. 5 demonstrate that this system is capable of photoelectron measurements at elevated pressures, covering a wide range from UHV to 30 Torr. This high limit of pressure of 30 Torr is important because it is above the saturated vapor pressure of water at room temperature; thus, it is sufficient to perform in situ studies of aqueous systems using this instrument. 5 Scientific case studies In the previous section, we discussed how some key parameters affect the system performance. In the following section, we provide experimental examples to demonstrate how this system enables operando studies of interfacial electrochemical reactions. During the experiment, the working electrode was grounded so that the Fermi level of the electrode sample was aligned to that of the electron energy analyzer. In this way, the electrode core-level peaks remain unchanged regardless of the applied potential, whereas the features associated with the liquid electrolyte and gas phase above the liquid shift accordingly. 5.1 Following liquid phase changes at the electrochemical liquid/solid interface To ensure that the system can perform electrochemical experiments with liquids, we employed the “dip and pull” method (also known as the “meniscus” method) to stabilize the liquid/solid interface between a polycrystalline Pt foil and the 1 mol L–1 potassium fluoride electrolyte solution. The experimental procedures are described in detail in Refs. [ 19 ] and [ 23 ] and are discussed here only briefly. As shown in Fig. 2(d), a beaker containing 1 mol L–1 KF electrolyte with three electrodes was placed in the analysis chamber. Two Pt polycrystalline foils were used as the working electrode (WE) and counter electrode (CE), respectively, with a homemade Ag/AgCl reference electrode (RE) (see Supplemental Information for more details of the homemade RE). The chamber pressure was maintained at 17–19 Torr, and a large-volume equalizing reservoir was placed inside the chamber. The spectra were first collected at water vapor pressure (bottom line of Figs. 6(a)–(c)). The three electrodes were then immersed in the electrolyte solution and cycled between –0.715 and 1.385 V (vs. SHE) during electrochemical cleaning. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) of the Pt electrode in 1 mol L L–1 KF is shown in Fig. 6(d) [ 44 ]. After the CV signal stabilized with the potential held at –0.065 V, all electrodes were slowly and partially pulled out of the solution. This reduction potential ensured the reduced state of the Pt WE [ 19,45 ]. By using this “dip and pull” procedure, an electrolyte film with a thickness on the order of a few tens of nanometers was obtained on the WE surface. Thickness within this range is critical because the liquid film must be thin enough to allow the detection of the photoelectron signal from the WE yet thick enough to preserve behaviors representative of the bulk electrolyte [ 19 ]. The Pt electrode was positioned at the intersection of the X-ray beam and the focal point of the electron energy analyzer for photoelectron measurements of the electrode/electrolyte interface. Because the electrodes remained partially immersed in the electrolyte solution, the electrolyte thin film created on the electrode was electrically connected to the bulk electrolyte to ensure electrochemical continuity and, thus, allowed electrochemical control. This is also critical to prevent potentiostat overload. Representative spectra as a function of the applied potential are shown in Figs. 6(a)–(c). This demonstrates the capability of observing core-level features from the electrode substrate and those associated with the liquid electrolyte. It took approximately 30, 20, and 40 min to obtain the O 1s, Pt 3d 5/2, and Pt 4f spectra, respectively. Under water vapor pressure conditions, the peaks at BEs of 71.0, 74.3, and 2121.8 eV were assigned to Pt 4f 7/2, 4f 5/2, and 3d 5/2 of metallic Pt, respectively [ 19,45 ]. The chemisorbed water was identified at 532.6 eV [ 19 ]. After the liquid electrolyte film had formed and was subjected to an applied potential that increased from –0.065 to 1.235 V, small shoulder peaks associated with Pt2+ appeared at 72.4, 75.7, and 2123.1 eV. Although the corresponding oxidized components were mostly buried in the O 1s spectra, features associated with the vapor atmosphere and the liquid electrolyte could be clearly observed. With the liquid film covering the Pt WE, the O 1s spectra became dominated by the relatively wide peak of liquid water at approximately 533 eV. The BE of this component was systematically shifted from high to low as a function of the applied potential from –0.065 to 1.235 V vs. SHE, giving a 1:1 shift, as shown in Fig. 6(e). This observation is consistent with previous electrochemical APXPS investigations [ 45 ]. In a future study of the electrochemical liquid/solid interface, this system can be used to investigate the electrochemical reaction mechanism and electrical double layer. 5.2 Following the discharge products of a Na-O2 battery at the gas/solid interface In addition to liquid/solid interfaces, studies of interesting electrochemical processes at solid/gas interfaces using in situ spectroscopy are useful from the perspective of fundamental research and practical applications. In this section, we provide an example of sodium-oxygen (Na-O2) model battery studies to demonstrate how electrochemical reactions can occur at gas/solid interfaces under operando conditions using this APXPS system. Rechargeable metal-oxygen batteries are a promising energy storage technology. Owing to their high theoretical specific energy (1600 Wh kg–1) and equilibrium discharge potential of 2.3 V, rechargeable Na-O2 batteries have drawn significant interest in recent years. However, their practical implementation is limited by low energy efficiencies and poor cycle lives. These problems are largely related to the discharge products that are insoluble and highly reactive towards the key components of the battery. Therefore, it is desirable to identify the discharge products responsible for the limited performance and develop strategies to tailor the electrode structure/composition to prevent the formation of such discharge products. Our test case was a Na-O2 model battery [ 46 ]. The test battery consisted of a sodium anode separated from a porous cathode by a sodium-ion conducting electrolyte. The cross-section of this model battery is schematically shown in Fig. 7(a) , along with a photograph of the experiment. Sodium metal (Alfa Aesar, 99%) was sealed in a stainless steel container. A ceramic Na-β″-Al2O3 membrane (10.5-mm diameter and 0.7-mm thickness, Ionotec) was used as the sodium-ion-conducting electrolyte. The cathode was prepared by coating silver paint (SPI, 05001-AB) on the other side of the electrolyte membrane. After assembly, the battery was secured onto the PEEK electrode housing, and the Ag cathode side was commonly grounded to the electron energy analyzer and exposed for X-ray photoelectron spectra measurements. The Na anode side was subjected to potential control to discharge or charge the battery. Fig. 7(b) shows the discharge-charge curves of the model battery measured in a water-oxygen atmosphere (11 Torr H2O and 4 Torr O2, 60% relative humidity). Under these conditions, an open-circuit voltage of approximately 2.5 V was measured. Upon discharge, Na stripping occurred at the Na metal anode side, whereas oxygen reduction reaction took place on the cathode side. When the battery was charged, this corresponded to Na plating at the anode and oxygen evolution at the Ag electrode. At a constant current of 8 μA, the battery was first discharged to 0.04 mA h. We observed a discharge voltage plateau at approximately 2.1 V. Fig. 7(c) plots the Na 1s and O 1s spectra recorded on the Ag cathode surface before discharge and after discharge to 0.016 and 0.04 mA h. After subtracting the Shirley-type background, the Na 1s and O 1s spectra were normalized to the intensity of their low-BE background region. The Na 1s and O 1s spectra were fitted using a Gauss-Lorentz line shape (GL(30), i.e., 70% Gaussian and 30% Lorentzian). The BE of each species were unchanged during the charge and discharge processes, and the FWHM was limited to 1.2–1.5 eV. As discharge proceeded, signals corresponding to Na began to appear at a BE of 1072 eV, indicating the formation of Na species on the Ag cathode surface. Correspondingly, the O 1s spectra showed a clear increase in the intensities of features related to liquid/condensed H2O at 533.5 eV, OH– at 532 eV, and CO3 2– at 531 eV [ 47,48 ]. The simultaneous changes observed in the Na 1s and O 1s spectra suggest that the discharged products were likely NaOH and Na2CO3 [ 46,48,49 ]. Notably, NaOH was the only discharge product during the first 2 h of discharge, and Na2CO3 was not observed until the late stages of discharge. The presence of NaOH is reasonable for this battery, and the formation of Na2CO3 could be a result of the reaction of NaOH with residual gas in the chamber or with the silver paint [ 46,49 ]. The battery was then charged at the same constant current, and representative spectra collected at 0.024 and 0.00 mA h are shown in Fig. 7(c). A small decrease in the intensity was observed when the battery was charged from 0.04 to 0.024 mA h. However, even when the battery was completely charged, the sodium-oxygen species remained on the Ag electrode surface. This failure to decompose the discharge products when charging the battery is probably responsible for the inferior energy efficiency and short cycle life. Interestingly, the carbonate component in the O 1s spectrum continued to grow in intensity during charging, whereas the sodium peak slightly decreased. This could be related to the conversion of NaOH to Na2CO3 [ 46,49 ], as suggested above, and may also depend on the near-surface structure and reaction kinetics at a given charge-discharge current. A more fundamental correlation between these parameters is currently under investigation and will be reported in future work. 6 Experimental considerations We have reported two applications of operando APXPS to follow electrochemical phenomena at liquid/solid and gas/solid interfaces. The application of APXPS to electrochemical investigations makes it possible to obtain chemical-specific information concerning electrochemical reactions during electrocatalysis and, thus, obtain important mechanistic insights. However, the knowledge gained from such studies is not without error. Crucially, the physics of photoelectron spectroscopy, design of electrochemical cells, choice of material system, and other experimental aspects also significantly affect the accuracy of the measurements and determine how much unambiguous information can be extracted. For instance, if a system is subject to interference owing to the overlapping of core-level peaks, it will be difficult to examine via photoelectron spectroscopy. Furthermore, at interfaces with multilayer structures, the top layer dominates the photoelectron signal, and changes in the bottom layer may be difficult to capture. Here we note a few other considerations that are of importance when one performs “dip and pull” experiments for operando APXPS in electrochemical systems. The “dip and pull” method is the most flexible method in regards of creating liquid/solid interfaces. The available working electrode materials include metal foils, oxides, and single crystals, which can provide a sufficiently large, macroscopically flat, and rigid surface to establish a well-defined meniscus. The typical sample size is approximately 50 × 5 × 0.5 mm3, but different dimensions can be accommodated, and metal foils must be polished to a mirror finish using silicon carbide papers of decreasing grain size (e.g., from 400 to 4000 grit), followed by thorough cleaning, rinsing, and drying. Flame annealing is often used to remove adventitious carbon, and hydrophilic surfaces are generally preferred, but this depends on the nature of the liquid electrolyte being investigated. There is little restriction on the counter electrodes as long as they are sufficiently large in surface area to ensure accurate electrochemical measurements [ 29 ]. In addition, the electrolyte containers should be thoroughly cleaned, for example, with potassium permanganate, sulfuric acid, hydrogen peroxide, and MilliQ water [ 50 ]. Before being introduced into the analysis chamber, the prepared electrolyte solution needs to be outgassed at low pressures (10–15 Torr) for at least 30 min to remove dissolved gases. Although purging inert gases through the electrolyte is a common method of degassing in most electrochemical studies, it is somewhat different in APXPS studies; specifically, degassing liquid electrolytes under light vacuum is preferred. This is to avoid splashing the electrolyte solution into the electron energy analyzer, which can damage the system. Another experimental challenge related to the “dip and pull” method concerns the limited mass transportation of the electrolyte film. When probing an interfacial phenomenon that involves a rigorous Faradaic reaction, the mass transport limitation in the electrolyte film can result in appreciable deviations of the observed behaviors from the real electrochemical phenomena. In particular, the loss of potential control [ 45,51 ] and underestimation of the effective current density and pH at the measurement spot are among some reported cases [ 45 ]. These concerns can be experimentally addressed by using a supporting electrolyte or by tailoring electrode morphologies to enhance the mass transport in the direction parallel to the solid electrode surface [ 51 ]. In this sense, the “dip and pull” method is particularly suitable for studying static electrochemical phenomena. Moreover, recent works have reported operando XPS studies of Al-ion batteries based on ionic-liquid electrolytes [ 52,53 ]. This provides an alternative route for operando XPS studies in electrochemistry. Finally, the effect of water radiolysis should be considered. Because the X-ray beam interacts with the condensed matter of the interface, it may cause the generation of radicals, which can interfere with observation by reacting with the probed electrocatalysts. Previous reports show that by improving the renewal of electrolyte liquids near the interface, this effect can be significantly minimized [ 54 ]. In this respect, a detailed experimental investigation of thin liquid films is still lacking and is essential for addressing these challenges. 7 Summary In summary, we have described a state-of-the-art electrochemical APXPS system focusing on the synergy that is possible when electrochemistry and XPS at ambient pressures are integrated for operando measurements. In particular, we developed a new lab-based tender X-ray APXPS system dedicated to in situ and operando spectroscopic analyses. In this paper, we have explained the functions of each instrument component and provided an overview of the core principles of APXPS. Further, the presented case studies involving both liquid/solid and gas/solid interfaces demonstrate how APXPS can be employed to advance our experimental toolkit to observe interfacial chemistry, electric potential shifts, and discharge/charge products during operation directly. These measurements could be extremely valuable to electrochemists in their attempts to elucidate electrochemical processes or tailor interfaces for improved performance. Lastly, we have shared our personal view on the experimental challenges of electrochemical APXPS research, which are simultaneous opportunities for methodology development. We hope that this discussion will be beneficial for planning future experiments using this or similar systems to obtain a complete picture of the working liquid/solid interface. We also believe that this work can enable a better understanding of this advanced in situ technique by the electrochemistry community. Finally, we emphasize that corporate efforts in instrument development for electrochemical studies are of vital importance, especially because this could determine the accuracy of operando APXPS data analysis and drive technical improvements in APXPS. We hope that the present work will provide inspiration along this path. coredata.dc:description: Electrocatalysis is key to improving energy efficiency, reducing carbon emissions, and providing a sustainable way of meeting global energy needs. Therefore, elucidating electrochemical reaction mechanisms at the electrolyte/electrode interfaces is essential for developing advanced renewable energy technologies. However, the direct probing of real-time interfacial changes, i.e., the surface intermediates, chemical environment, and electronic structure, under operating conditions is challenging and necessitates the use of in situ methods. Herein, we present a new lab-based instrument commissioned to perform in situ chemical analysis at liquid/solid interfaces using ambient pressure X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (APXPS). This setup takes advantage of a chromium source of tender X-rays and is designed to study liquid/solid interfaces by the “dip and pull” method. Each of the main components was carefully described, and the results of performance tests are presented. Using a three-electrode setup, the system can probe the intermediate species and potential shifts across the liquid electrolyte/solid electrode interface. In addition, we demonstrate how this system allows the study of interfacial changes at gas/solid interfaces using a case study: a sodium–oxygen model battery. However, the use of APXPS in electrochemical studies is still in the early stages, so we summarize the current challenges and some developmental frontiers. Despite the challenges, we expect that joint efforts to improve instruments and the electrochemical setup will enable us to obtain a better understanding of the composition–reactivity relationship at electrochemical interfaces under realistic reaction conditions.
